Award.AwardTitle: Effective Descriptions of Quantum Gravity and Cosmology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The main aim of this project is to complete the formulation of effective descriptions of quantum systems in canonical language. Especially the field of canonical quantum gravity (including loop quantum gravity) requires a more general setting than standard effective actions, allowing for instance for an enlarged gauge structure, general covariance and the associated freedom to change the time variable, and a non-Gaussian or non-vacuum state as expansion basis. Compared to existing formulations, the major extension provided by work in the project will lead to a canonical version of effective quantum field theory. Applications will include an analysis of renormalization in canonical quantum gravity, comparisons with existing results in effective quantum gravity to check the low-energy limit of loop quantum gravity, as well as structure formation in the early universe and possible restrictions on initial states.

Quantum gravity is expected to be important at high energy density, for instance in the early universe during or just after the big-bang. In such regimes, space-time itself, and not just matter in space-time, is described by a wave function subject to quantum uncertainty and fluctuations. For several conceptual and technical reasons, it is difficult to evaluate such wave functions for potential physical observations, but as in particle physics, their implications can often be approximated and derived using effective equations. Standard methods of particle physics are not directly applicable to quantum gravity, in which the classical structure of space-time is no longer available. This project aims to complete the setting of effective equations suitable for quantum gravity, a process in which several questions of mathematical interest (such as Poisson geometry and algebraic structures) will be touched as well. It will contribute to physical cosmology by providing new scenarios and equations for structure formation in the early universe that include quantum-gravity effects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While quantum mechanics and general relativity are well-understood and experimentally tested theories, a consistent theory that combines them remains elusive. This project has evaluated promising methods in new models, and has led to some generalizations required for instance to deal with the notion of relative time in quantum physics. Other extensions apply to so-called non-associative quantum mechanics, in which the product of three or more factors depends on the way it is split into pairwise multiplications. Physically, such systems are expected to appear by some quantum space-time effects, or in the presence of magnetic monopoles.

One of the questions to be addressed by combinations of quantum mechanics and general relativity is how symmetries are realized, in particular the symmetry of general covariance which implies that physical predictions are independent of the choice of coordinates. The classical theory of general relativity obeys this important symmetry, but quantum effects are expected to modify the field equations, and the preservation of symmetries is not guaranteed. For instance, a discrete, lattice-like structure of space-time could break rotational and Lorentz symmetries which are important in particle physics. In this project, several models have been analyzed, showing that some proposals that have been made do not respect general covariance. In other cases, it turned out to be possible to respect covariance, but only if we change our picture of space-time at high density, realized for instance close to the big bang or in black holes. The resulting phenomenon of signature change, according to which space-time is replaced by 4-dimensional space at high density, has been investigated in detail and supported further.

Some of the methods developed in this project have been applied to fields not related to gravity, such as magnetic-monopole systems. They have also given rise to new mathematical problems in the context of non-associative algebras. As other broader impacts, the results have been widely disseminated by contributions to popular accounts of science, several review articles, and lextures at universities, conferences and summer schools. Throughout the project, undergraduate and graduate students have gained research experience by working on individual questions, and some of the research has been used for examples in teaching.
